captions.text: LARRY KOSILLA: Hey, guys.

Larry here from ammonyc.com,
and today I'm here at

Rennwerks Porsche in
Elmsford, New York.

Now, this is the premiere
Porsche restoration shop in

all of the Western hemisphere,
as far as I'm concerned.

And last night, I got a phone
call from the head guru here,

Cheech Fernandes, asking me
to come in and take a
look at a 911 SC.

Apparently there's some bumps
on the surface, but we're
going to find out from him.

All coming up today on this
episode of Drive Clean.
[MUSIC PLAYING]

CHEECH FERNANDES: Larry, I'm
glad you're here You gotta
help me out with this car.

LARRY KOSILLA: That
sounds awful.
What happened to it?

CHEECH FERNANDES: We
did a lot of work
and the paint's terrible.

I want to make the car look
good for a client.

He's spending a lot
of money with me.
So do me a favor, Larry--

make me look good and bail
me out this time.

LARRY KOSILLA: No problem
I'll take care of it.
CHEECH FERNANDES: Thank you.

LARRY KOSILLA: It looks
like we got a lot of
work ahead of us.

We're going to clay this
car right now.

Remember 20 years ago when all
you needed was a tub of

compound and an old rag
to clean your car?
Those days are long gone.

With the invention of clear
coats, we have these amazing
products called clay.

Now in the 1980s in Japan, some
genius came up with this
right here.

It actually looks
like Play-Doh.

Now I've mashed into a
hamburger-shape style here,

and what I'm going to do is
lubricate this little area and

run it past and go in
straight lines back
and forth, no circles.

And what it's going to do is
going to pick up the embedded

dirt, grime, road
sap, brake dust,
overspray, things like that.

This rough sound, it's actually
going to pick that up

and remove it from
the clear coat.
Let me show you how it works.

First thing you do is you take
some lubrication, either spray

wax or clay lube, and spray
it on both sides.

Now that we have the area nice
and lubed up, take it just
like this, straight lines.
Can you hear it?

Now as I make more and more
passes, that sound's going to
get quieter.
Why?

Because all the sap, all the
nasty stuff that's in this

clear coat is now going
to be in the clay.

It takes no time to do this and
drastically improves the
appearance of your car.
Hear it getting quieter?

That's all the embedded stuff
getting caught in this clay.
So here we go--
look at that.

Everything that was in the clear
coat is now on here.

This is so sticky that it peels
it off the clear coat
without scratching it.

This is one of the best
inventions to come to cars in
a long, long time.

Now that the clay is full,
meaning both sides are full of

contaminants, what you want
to do is knead it.

You go like this, recrush it,
spin it around, and then once

again, get it back into a
hamburger sized shape.
See how sticky it is?

Once you knead it and get a
fresh area, you can, again,
use it on lights and glass.

That's what's so versatile
about this clay.

You can use it on glass, too--
use it the same way.

Add lubrication, do the same
thing to the glass-- add

lubrication, and of course,
straight lines, front to back,
just like this.

This is going to pick
all the embedded--
hear it?

It's going to pick up all be
embedded bugs and dust and

anything you've hit
on the road.

This is a great way to get
some clarity to this
windshield.

Now another cool thing that you
can do with clay, because

once it gets full like this I'm
not going to use it on the
paint, because guess what?

It's already shot, but just
before the end of its life,

before I throw it away, I take
a little piece off just like

this, I break it off, and I use
it on the rims, and you
can use these just like that.

Hit it with a little
lubrication, same here, take a

little piece, get in there
with your finger, and now

you're pulling up all the
embedded brake dust that you

wouldn't normally get when
you're washing the wheels.
Now check this out--
boom.

All right, so we've seen how
clay works, and it's probably
the best tool in your garage.

It's cheap, it's easy, it's
quick, and it does amazing
stuff to the car.

So we've shown how it works on
the paint, we've shown how it

works on the lights, the glass,
and even the rims, but

the big thing here is to see
the difference, and to hear

the difference, so I'm going
to show you right now.
Listen--
this is untouched paint.

I'm going to use the same
pressure, pull my hand across
the paint, and listen to it.
Go back again, same pressure.

So now this paint is
completely clean.

Now if I wanted to, I'd either
polish or compound or wax or

seal, but I have nothing in
between the clear coat and the
product that I'm using.

It's all because of this
right here, clay.

See, there's still a little bit
of boogers left in here.

Like any professional, I'm
not going to practice new

techniques or work with new
products on a $2.5 or $3
million car.

So what I do is I go to the
body shop, and I rummage

around and find cool parts just
like this to practice on.

So the biggest thing that I
see when people use this

amazing product clay is they're
working on the car and

whoops, it falls
on the ground.

And of course, you're going to
get some rocks and little

things in here that
you don't want.
This is sticky, remember.

So what they do is they pick it
out-- you never get all of

it-- and the next thing they do
is they go to their car and

they're saying, let's finish
the clay process.

So let's find out what happens
when you use a dirty clay bar
on fresh paint.

Put a little lube on here,
wipe this off--
oh, my gosh.
Now take a close look at this.

All these little rocks that were
embedded here that you

can't pick off now are just
crushed into the paint.

So anytime your clay bar falls
onto the ground, touches the

ground, or touches anything
other than the
paint, throw it away.

For more information on how to
clay your car, check out our

step by step .pdf downloadable
at ammonyc.com.
I'm Larry from Drive Clean.
Thanks for watching.
[MUSIC PLAYING]

title: Clay: The Best Tool in Your Garage! - /DRIVE CLEAN

comments.text:
Also Another question, it is advised to remove the wax coating on your car 
before clay bar process, is this really necessary, and will the clay bar 
process remove polish or only contaminants?﻿
comments.author: Azza ​

comments.text:
I gotta say, when I attempted clay bar-ing, it was on my midnight purple 
skyline, thing is.... I ended up streaking it and swirling it, even after I 
did a clean, I am a bit paranoid to go back and do that again now... I 
still can't figure out why, was I using too much pressure? Dirt on the bar 
perhaps? Idk...﻿
comments.author: Azza ​

comments.text:
+Azza ​ You had stuff in the clay and made swirls in it or you already had 
swirls on the pain.
comments.author: Marcello Wheeler

comments.text:
The only thing I'd suggest is not to use both sides.  Use ONE SIDE, then 
when you're ready for a fresh spot, just fold the dirty side on itself.  No 
kneading, no exposed dirt still on the surface from kneading.  Voila, 
(near) infinite use...﻿

comments.author: Azza ​

comments.text:
If your car has never been clayed before, should you strip off the wax 
using dishwashing soap, before doing this? Would there be a better/safer 
option to dishwashing soap? I'm thinking there could be all sorts of gunk 
in the existing wax that would affect the quality of the final finish.﻿
comments.author: dalriada842

comments.text:
+SimplySerenity
One thing I've noticed when using dish soap for stripping, is that it can 
be a little harsh on exterior trim. A few pieces of black trim on my car 
became a little discolored and stained after the first use of dish soap, 
but I used one ounce in a 5 gallon bucket, probably could have done 50/50 
with regular car soap, but still get the stripping qualities of the dish 
soap.
comments.author: Nickhead87

comments.text:
I would say yes, you should strip away the wax since the point is to get a 
completely clean clear coat, which you can then seal again with sealant or 
wax. 

As for not using dishwashing soap I don't know if there is a better option 
but it should be perfectly safe. It's not really strong enough to damage 
your paint, it's just strong enough to break up the wax.
comments.author: SimplySerenity

comments.text:
Your videos truly inspire me to detail and maintain a clean car , thank you!
P.S. The music in the videos are great!﻿
comments.author: Noel Gutierrez

comments.text: How can I gauge when to use a new piece of clay. Any particular method ? ﻿

comments.text:
After kneading so many times, you won't see any clean clay left, this is a 
good time to grab a new piece of clay.

 that i saw, i proceeded to go out the next day and bought a kit 
containing, a bottle of detailer, a small clay bar, and a cheap microfiber

after i hit it with a decent polish, and a good wax..now washing takes no

advice. ﻿

comments.text:
Yes. If your swirl marks are deep, you may want to use a compound before 
the polish. Wheels, wash, clay, compound and/or polish, wax/sealant.

comments.text: He means spit, the quick detailer, skin is the sealent.

How come these clay bars are so freaking expensive? Like a simple 200gram 
bar costs over 50 dollar, anyone got some tips of good clays for a cheap

comments.author: Minutemadex

comments.text:
you can try ordering them online through detailing websites.  buffdaddy.com 
should have them in bulk.  buying in bulk will save you a little, if you're 
planning on using a lot of clay, but quality tools tend to cost a premium. 
That's just the way it goes.
comments.author: MrSierra5000

comments.text:
i got petzolds clay on amazon. 100gr for 11 €. it has good reviews and 
worked fine for me
comments.author: jerri0401

comments.text:
Because the manufactures, distributors and retailers all make a ton of 
money on them.

My tips to get a good price, buy direct from the distributor if you can - 
many of them have warehouse shops or online stores, and you can save a 
bundle by knocking out the retailer.

My local distributor has clearance sales on their website to get rid of old 
product when the manufacturer comes out with new packaging or version of 
the product, so I keep an eye out for bargains and buy up a pile when they 
go on special.

I've been using Meguires quik clay which is one of the cheaper ones and 
comes with a pretty decent quick detailer in the box too that works great 
as a lubricant - unlike many other detailing products where you get what 
you pay for, they all work the same so as far as I can tell it's totally 
pointless not buying the cheapest one you can find.
comments.author: Matthew Sharpe

comments.text: Don't forget metal and plastic too!﻿
comments.author: Sungodv

comments.text: PERFECT VIDEO! i'm going to be doing this to my brand new car soon..﻿
comments.author: Lan Yu

comments.text:
um. why show a clay bar that just picked up a bunch of stuff from an 
unwashed rim and act like its working so good its amazing? would have been 
better to just wash the wheel real quick and then use it to see what it 
really picked up. kind of lost me at that point﻿
comments.author: Ian Mears

comments.text:
+stephen james You're right about the fact that you can use a DA without 
claying to remove defects, but taking the time you clay before hand will 
prevent all those contaminants from imbedding inside the pad you're 
polishing with and that will in turn reduce the amount of times you have to 
clean the pads out between passes.  Stripping all contaminants off the 
paint prior will make for a cleaner surface to polish on and will reduce 
your workload as a result.
comments.author: MrSierra5000

comments.text:
Yeah I agree with your comment, its a no brainer  I don't see the point in 
this claying fad, Correct cleaning and polishing as at Aston Martin, Bently 
or Rolls Royce would use a D.A and good old fashioned elbow grease- just 
check out the Royals cars over here paintwork like a mirror. My Mars Red 
GTI looks spectacular. Clay money making scam.

comments.text: Using a claybar too much also rips off your clear coat off
comments.author: Ben Sell

comments.text: Great tutorials, guys.
comments.author: vicdmise

comments.text:
If you drop the clay, can you just pick the big bits out and re-knead the 
clay into a fresh lump? I think that's what Griot's recommends with their 
clay...
comments.author: TheOriginalDoctorG

comments.text:
Possibly if the paint is seriously contaminated. I recently clayed a 
co-worker's car and the clay got so gunked up, I had to continuously knead 
the clay to keep it from getting loaded up. More aggressive clay bars can 
mar the paint, especially if a lot of pressure is used. It's best to move 
the clay in quick back and forth motions with light pressure, sometimes no 
pressure. It all depends on how contaminated the paint is. Just knead the 
clay to expose a new clean surface as it gets gross.
comments.author: Nickhead87

comments.text:
I personally like Wolgfang poly clay. It's kind of pricey, but it's 200 
gram bar, which will easily split up into at least 3 pieces. It's nice and 
sturdy feeling, but not too aggressive and still pliable.
comments.author: Nickhead87

comments.author: Stephen Chen

comments.text:
The best way to really tell if you need to clay it or not is to put ur hand 
in a thin plastic bag, and very gently feel you're paint and you'll be 
amazed how intensely dirty it can feel, even though you think it's 
perfectly clean right after a wash and everything. For me personally, I 
only clay the car if I'm about to wax or polish it, to keep from causing 
scratches and things while rubbing the wax or whatever on and so that the 
product can get to the paint better and do it's job.
comments.author: killamanjaro306

comments.text: PORSCHE IS A TWO SYLLABLE WORD!
comments.author: Philocognition

comments.text:
Doesn't matter what you use. If you buy a clay bar kit at a parts store it 
comes with clay lube. Spray wax works exactly the same, but so does car 
soap. Just use what you have and make sure that if you do use car soap it's 
wit clean water, not the dirty water you have left over after a wash.
